Method: fMRI, diffusion MRI
ATUM-SEM
Notes:
Using the MICrONS dataset, this study reveals a universal "like-to-like" connectivity rule in the mouse visual cortex, where neurons
with similar features preferentially connect. These principles, mirrored in artificial networks, highlight their role in sensory processing and learning.

Dataset name:
Behavioral and neuroimaging data collected pre-pandemic and
during the pandemic from a cohort of university students
Acquisition Time (days):
Neuroimaging data collected over multiple sessions pre-pandemic
(October 2019‚ÄìJanuary 2020) and follow-up assessments during
March‚ÄìApril 2021
Method:
Resting-state functional MRI (rs-fMRI), Regularized Canonical Correlation Analysis
(rCCA), nested cross-validation, machine learning pipeline (linear SVM)
Notes:
The study highlights functional connectivity patterns predictive of stress and anxiety during the COVID-19
pandemic and suggests implications for targeted psychological interventions.

Volume(as quoted):
Not explicitly quoted;
dataset contains 879 neonatal brain scans
Dataset Size (TB): 2-3 TB per cohort for neuroimaging data
Acquisition Time (days):
DL-based pipeline ~24 seconds per scan;
original pipeline - 6.5 hours per scan
Method:
Deep Learning-based cortical surface reconstruction using GPU acceleration
and multi-scale deformation networks
Notes:
The study introduced a GPU-accelerated pipeline for reconstructing neonatal brain surfaces, achieving 995x speed improvements
over the original method with superior accuracy.

Dataset Size (TB): not given( includes sample size 55,384 peptide-GPCR pairs)
Method: Reverse pharmacology, calcium mobilization assays
Notes:
Identified 461 peptide-GPCR pairs using a comprehensive screening of synthetic peptides. Found evolutionary conservation of 14 bilaterian
peptidergic systems in C. elegans.

Acquisition Time (days): not applicable used earlier dataset of HCP
Method:
Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), geodesic tractography, Riemannian
manifold modeling, CEDNN
Notes:
Demonstrates the utility of convolutional encoder-decoder neural networks (CEDNN) for brain connectome modelling
and improved alignment of fiber tracts.

Method:
Serial Block-Face Electron Microscopy (SBFSEM), automated and manual
segmentation using Eyewire, convolutional neural network-based reconstruction
Completion %:
Partial -199 starburst cells reconstructed
and analyzed, but dataset boundary and
incomplete nuclear layer reconstruction
limit full completion
Notes:
The study identified novel perisomatic contacts between starburst amacrine cells, challenging prior assumptions about their
stratification and connectivity.

Dataset name: EM dataset of larval zebrafish brain
Method: Serial block-face scanning EM (SEBM)
Notes:
Dense synaptic connectivity reconstruction using SBEM, paired with 2P calcium imaging. Synapse-level analysis was validated by
SyConn, and a digital neuron address book was created for circuit mapping.

Dataset Size (TB): not given (it mentions that it's a big dataset)
Method: Serial Section Electron Microscopy, Automated Image Analysis, Statistical Modeling
Notes:
This study maps L2/3 pyramidal cell connectivity in the mouse visual cortex using electron microscopy, revealing synapse size as a combination of
binary and analogue variables. Binary variation aligns with uniform activity-dependent plasticity, while analogue variation reflects spontaneous
fluctuations, supporting the hypothesis of bistable synaptic states in learning.

Volume(as quoted):
1,130 cm3 (estimated but not
specified in the paper)
Method:
Compressed sensing, connectome spectrum-based tomographic
reconstruction of EEG sources; integration of fMRI, diffusion MRI,
and graph signal processing
Notes: The study introduced Connectome Spectrum Electromagnetic Tomography (CSET) to enhance EEG source reconstruction by leveraging sparse representations of brain connectivity.

Resolution (nm):
fMRI spatial resolution 0.9 mm
slice thickness (approx)
functional resolution TR = 2s
Dataset Size (TB): just specifies a lower TB range of data
Acquisition Time (days): Longitudinal study with imaging at 2 days and 30 days post-injury
Method:
Resting-state functional MRI (11.1 T), graph theory-based connectivity analysis,
modularity analysis, Pearson correlation matrices
Notes:
The study demonstrates compensatory functional connectivity reorganization in response to controlled cortical impact. Graph-theory metrics
were used to analyze connectivity patterns and recovery trends post-TBI.

Acquisition Time (days): 18‚Äì343 days for retest sessions; original acquisition took years
Method:
Structural, functional, and diffusion-weighted MRI; probabilistic tractography;
sparse matrix representations; high-resolution cortical maps and connectome computation
Notes:
This study developed high-resolution connectomic methods to predict behaviour and identity, emphasizing individual
differences in cortical and connectomic properties.

Dataset name: Not explicitly named; data acquired using the SMART pipeline
Method:
Serial sectioning, PuClear tissue clearing, VISoR2 fluorescence microscopy, and
semiautomated volume reconstruction using the SMART pipeline
Notes:
This study established a scalable workflow for mesoscale mapping of the monkey brain, revealing cortical and thalamic projection pathways.
Significant improvements in imaging speed and dataset handling were demonstrated.

Method: Light microscopy with immunostaining and molecular specificity
Notes: Uses a novel multiplexed antigen detection strategy involving multiple rounds of immunostaining, imaging, and stripping

Method: FIB-SEM
Notes: First large-scale human tissue study

Method: Confocal Microscopy
Notes:
Data acquisition time not mentioned- Individual experiments involved a 2-minute waiting period, followed by a 4-minute recording.
Additional waiting times between stimuli and preparations are mentioned.

Organism: HeLa cells and U-2OS cells (human cell lines)
Dataset name: pan-ExM processed datasets (referred as this but no specific name)
Acquisition Time (days): not specifically mentioned, but a few minutes per participant over a few days
Method: Confocal Microscopy,Expansion microscopy (pan-ExM), fluorescence microscopy, and STED
Notes:
Developed pan-ExM, enabling 13- to 21-fold expansion of samples, retaining ultrastructure while achieving nanoscale resolution.
Process compatible with immunolabeling and fluorescent dyes.

Method: FIB-SEM
Notes:
New methods, including advanced tissue preparation, high-resolution imaging, data alignment, automated segmentation,
synapse detection, and proofreading tools, enabled the mapping of a large portion of the Drosophila melanogaster
central brain. The publicly accessible dataset simplifies circuit analysis, linking neurons to genetic tools and offering
insights into brain organization and evolutionary packing efficiency.

Method:
Electron microscopy (EM), semi-automated 3D segmentation,
Neu3 software for proofreading
Notes:
The study introduced Neu3, a tool combining 3D visualization and graph-based segmentation, to enhance proofreading workflows and
scalability for large connectomic datasets.

Acquisition Time (days): Data collection and processing spanned 50+ person-years
Method:
Serial-section electron microscopy (ssEM), automated segmentation with
machine learning, manual proofreading
Notes:
The study represents the largest and most detailed connectome reconstruction to date, revealing 25,000 neurons and 20 million synapses
 in the fruit fly's central brain.

not specific
but low and high both
resolution used

optogenetics, behavioral testing, BDNF overexpression
Notes:
Findings- Persistent spontaneous pain disrupts vCA1-IL connectivity, which can be rescued via genetic interventions (BDNF overexpression,
chemogenetics).

Notes: Achieved the largest dense reconstruction of cortical connectomes, introducing scalable annotation strategies. Provided insights into Hebbian plasticity and connectomic cell-type definitions.

1150-direction diffusion MRI, super-resolution track density imaging (TDI),

The study mapped hippocampal connectivity using ultra-high angular resolution diffusion MRI, identifying six dominant pathways and
quantifying age- and gender-related effects.

Notes:

a connectivity matrix.

Method: MRI, fMRI and MEG

 with 25 major tracts

The study highlighted challenges in tractography with phantom data, emphasizing false-positive connections and the need for methodological
improvements in brain connectivity mapping.

Method: Serial-section electron microscopy, manual proofreading, and graph-based modeling
Notes:
This study mapped the entire mushroom body connectome at synaptic resolution, identifying 223 Kenyon cells, modulatory neurons, and extensive
connectivity motifs.

This study improved automated connectome reconstruction by integrating deep structured learning with large-scale graph-based segmentation
techniques.

Method: Diffusion Magnetic Resonance Imaging (dMRI), multi-shell acquisition, tractography

Advances in multi-shell imaging improved angular, spatial, and temporal resolution, enabling the reconstruction of challenging brain
pathways like retinofugal and brainstem.

Method:

machine learning-based segmentation, and convolutional neural networks for boundary
detection
Notes:
The study reconstructed 950 neurons in the IPL, characterized a new bipolar cell type, and identified circuit motifs predicting
motion sensitivity. Data was validated with known circuits and is publicly accessible.

Acquisition Time (days):
~10 days per neuron for light microscopy reconstruction; months
 for electron microscopy of smaller dendritic or axonal regions
Method:
Sparse reconstruction using light microscopy (LM) for large-scale dendritic/
axonal arborization, electron microscopy (EM) for synaptic profiles, and computational
modelling to link physiology and anatomy
Notes:
The study emphasizes the limitations of current methods for large-scale connectomics and advocates for a sparse reconstruction strategy to
address key questions about neural circuit organization and computation.

Method:
High-pressure freezing, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), semi-
automated segmentation, manual proofreading, neuron classification via Golgi impregnation
 and genetic labelling.
Notes:
The study reconstructed a motion detection circuit, identifying key neurons (e.g., Mi1, Tm3, T4) involved in detecting directional motion in the fly
visual system. Data includes dense synaptic connectivity for the medulla.

Organism:
Drosophila melanogaster (larva, medulla, lobula)
and mammalian retina
Method:
Electron Microscopy (EM), probabilistic segmentation graphs,
GPR metric for evaluating segmentation quality, and manual correction prioritization.
Completion %:
Partial; segmentation of key regions reached
 >90% adjusted Rand index (ARI) accuracy
but did not fully reconstruct all regions due
to manual correction limits.
Notes:
The study introduced GPR (Generalized Probabilistic Rand Index) to evaluate segmentation quality without ground truth,
significantly reducing manual segmentation time while maintaining high accuracy in reconstructions.

Method:
Diffusion Spectrum Imaging (DSI), high-resolution structural MRI, multi-scale cortical
parcellations, and tractography algorithms
Notes:
This study introduced a multi-scale, normalized approach to human connectome mapping, focusing on reproducibility and robustness across
individuals and resolutions.

Acquisition Time (days): Each scan lasted ~20 minutes per participant; took several weeks
Method:
Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI), fast marching algorithm for connectivity, graph
theoretical analysis of weighted networks
Notes:
This study showed increased local connectivity in ASD, particularly in language and visual processing regions, correlating stronger connectivity
with better language performance in ASD.

The study introduced RESCOP, enabling high-accuracy neurite reconstruction, and analyzed the challenges of annotating
dense and complex neural tissue volumes.

connectivity patterns

The study introduced FlyCircuit, an open-access resource for neuron data, and developed a mesoscopic map of Drosophila brain circuits,
laying the groundwork for understanding neural connectivity and information flow.

Method:
High-resolution histological imaging, manual segmentation, and computational embedding
of digital reconstructions to analyse potential synaptic connectivity.
Notes:
This study developed a computational framework for estimating potential synaptic connectivity based on the proximity of axons and
dendrites, providing insights into hippocampal circuits.

Method:

Electron Microscopy (SBFSEM); segmentation via graph cuts, interactive editing, and
topology validation
Notes:
The study introduced algorithms for 3D neuronal structure reconstruction from EM data, focusing on segmentation, manual correction, and
validation methods for topological accuracy.

mesoscale and microscale connectomic datasets.

Brainbow revolutionized neural circuit visualization by enabling multicolor labelling of neurons, improving resolution,

Achieved sub-diffraction-limit resolution for 3D imaging, allowing detailed visualization of nanoscale cellular structures.
Demonstrated applicability for structural biology.

Notes:
The study demonstrated that neuronal positioning in C. elegans is optimized for wiring costs. Outliers in placement were linked to
developmental and functional roles.

Method:
Probabilistic tractography using diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) to map connections between
thalamic nuclei and cortical regions
Notes:
This study provided the first connectivity-based segmentation of thalamic gray matter in humans, identifying pathways and connections reproducible
across individuals.

Method: Serial section TEM
Notes:
The Caenorhabditis elegans nervous system consists of 302 neurons arranged in an invariant structure across 118 classes, with highly localized
connectivity and ~5000 chemical synapses, ~2000 neuromuscular junctions, and ~600 gap junctions. Neurons, with simple morphologies, form
connections in defined process bundles, facilitating precise synaptic organization.

Method: Ultrathin sectioning, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), manual tracing and analysis
Notes:
The study describes the ultrastructure of retinal rods and cones in pigs, revealing species-specific differences and advancing
understanding of mammalian photoreceptor anatomy.

Method:
Serial sectioning of retinal tissue, light and electron microscopy, manual tracing of ganglion
cells for circuit reconstruction
Notes:
This study provided a foundational view of retinal ganglion cell connectivity, demonstrating early methodologies for functional
architecture analysis in the visual system.
